Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A software product that empowers healthcare teams with community resource information and facilitates post-treatment care coordination.
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be to develop and test feasibility of a web-based software and machine learning technology that is able to empower healthcare teams with community resource information as well as facilitate coordination of post-treatment care. Lack of access to community resources such as housing, food and transportation (also known as social determinants of health) has been associated with negative health outcomes such as unplanned hospital readmissions and emergency room visits. This leads to high healthcare costs. Therefore, healthcare teams (i.e. social workers, case managers and discharge planners) spend a significant amount of time to locate appropriate community resources for their patients. Our innovation will leverage a community of healthcare professionals and the resource providers to ultimately find community resources for patients in a faster and less costly manner. The machine learning technology supported by this award will connect healthcare professionals with relevant community resources that ultimately reduces the cost and time associated with this process. A successful implementation of this technology will lead to improved post-treatment care outcomes for the patients and reduced cost of care.

The proposed project will develop and test the feasibility of a web-based software platform to empower healthcare professionals to share community resources. Novel machine learning technology will be developed to facilitate appropriate and efficient exchange of community resources. Healthcare professionals using the platform will be able to get onto the platform as well as search and share resources. The machine learning algorithm leverages the relationships of healthcare professionals and resource providers to coordinate community resource sharing. A successful implementation of this algorithm will provide substantial improvements on the ability to acquire timely community resources as compared current methods. The goal of this research is to validate whether the machine learning technology is able to help healthcare professionals identify appropriate community resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Summary: Access to competent community resources such as housing, food, transportation and prescribed medications - also known as social determinants of health has been shown to be critical in improving patients? health outcomes. The inability to access such resources has been associated with negative health outcomes such as increased emergency room visits, hospital readmissions and high substance use relapse rates, which translates into increased overall cost of healthcare. In a healthcare setting, community resource needs (e.g. housing, food, transportation) are typically addressed by healthcare teams of case managers, social workers, discharge planners and community health workers among others. However, community resources tend to be highly dynamic and fragmented within communities and therefore these professionals spend about a third of their time searching for such resources - precious time that could be used to deliver direct clinical services. Furthermore, these teams typically curate and store community resource information (e.g. local housing programs) in manual ?referral binders? which are duplicative, often outdated, and highly fragmented across disparate healthcare teams and facilities. Therefore, the main goal of this SBIR Phase I study was to develop and establish feasibility of a ?smart? web-based software product able to facilitate healthcare teams to curate, search and share competent community resources for their patients.

 

Project Outcomes - Intellectual Merit: This completed SBIR Phase I study advanced knowledge by developing and testing feasibility of a highly innovative software product that facilitates healthcare teams (i.e. case managers, social workers, discharge planners among others) to have near real-time access to competent community resources. This product is powered by novel machine learning technology that allows flow of community resource information within local communities and therefore enabling patients to access competent resources for their post-treatment care.  

 

Project Outcomes - Broader Impacts: The software product developed in this project has led to two broader societal impacts. First, patients with chronic illnesses (e.g. cancer, diabetes, congestive heart failure, substance use among others) are able to receive community resources that positively contribute to their post-treatment care and recovery. Second, healthcare teams are able to access community resources faster as compared to the current gold standard, which saves them time to focus on other clinical duties.

  

 


Last Modified: 04/30/2019
Modified by: Tom L Lee
